The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This reduction is accompanied by a loss of key signaling pathways and transcriptional factors, suggesting that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by a significant reduction in the complexity of the animal. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food will increase by 70% to meet this demand. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize yields and yields variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the diets of large herbivores. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet composition. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of large herbivores in the structure and function of African savannas.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely across businesses, and many businesses expect to remain open for the long term. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and intriguing questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system. The solar system is also the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system in detail.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother is a key factor in determining the reproductive output of mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between blood and tissue. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and the first line of defense against infection and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is also the site of communication between cells. This study reveals the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells and the properties of the network. The findings reveal that the network is highly efficient in the transmission of information and that the cells are organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. The findings have implications for understanding the endothelium as a whole and for developing new strategies for controlling vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which have been used to inform public health policy and to conduct research. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for conducting research. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders, including public health officials, epidemiologists, researchers, and the general public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for allosteric communication between these two domains. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter on activation.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of four representative anaerobic gut fungi that live in the digestive tracts of herbivores. These fungi are important members of the gut microbiome and are likely to be overlooked in studies of the microbiome. The results of this study provide a foundation for future studies of the natural products of anaerobic fungi and could lead to the discovery of new bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These results may also have implications for understanding the role of anxiety in human social behavior. View Full-Text

The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a challenging task. The use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors, some of which are unachievable by a single material. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the protein responsible for the red color of blood. The hemoglobin molecule is composed of four subunits, two alpha subunits and two beta subunits. The alpha and beta subunits are encoded by two different genes, and the ratio of the two subunits is important for the color of blood. The ratio of alpha to beta subunits is also important for the function of blood. In this study, we found that a protein, IGF2BP1, is involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), two highly frequent events in cancer. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1, a transcriptional target of SREBP1, sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have a number of side effects. We show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate store-operated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is a key event in the development of hypertension-induced vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the NWFP has not been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. The best candidates are then tested in vitro and in vivo, and the best candidate is found to be active against resistant pathogens. The approach is generalizable to other antibiotic classes and can be used to design new antibiotics for other pathogens. The approach is also applicable to other drug classes. The approach can be used to design new drugs for other diseases.

We introduce a deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems. The code is available at https://github.com/yashar-y/dilated_conv_net.git.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and tablets, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of these devices in the hours before bedtime has a significant impact on sleep. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has been shown to suppress melatonin levels, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce alertness the next morning. These effects may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules are consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America are consistent with the source of the rare earth-bearing magnetic grains. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which is a key trait of beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding habits in beetles. They also suggest that the evolution of beetle diversity may be more complex than previously thought.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the design of cultural evolution experiments and the interpretation of the results of previous experiments. They also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. Our results suggest that the relationship between population size and CCE is complex and context-dependent.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold decreased risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is believed to have formed by the crystallization of a liquid core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase of iron is the first nucleus, followed by the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our study also provides a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This article is valuable for understanding the formation of the inner core and the origin of the Earth. It also provides a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana addiction. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for developing effective treatments for marijuana addiction.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we use a recently developed modeling approach to link brain and behavioral data with computational models of language processing in humans. We find that the most powerful models of language processing in the human brain are also the most predictive of behavior. These models are based on simple recurrent networks, and their neural fits to brain data correlate with model accuracy on a task of language comprehension. Our results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the human brain may be using recurrent networks to process language in a manner that is highly predictive of the next word in a sentence. These findings have implications for our understanding of the brain’s mechanisms for language and may inform the development of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not stable. We introduce a new algorithm, which we prove to be stable, and we show that it is able to solve a number of problems that have been considered intractable. Our results have implications for the theory of stability in mathematics and for the theory of machine learning and deep learning in particular.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a lack of social distancing and mask-wearing. This has led to a prominent claim that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This claim is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which was subsequently cited in numerous news articles and scientific papers. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed until recently, and it is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has plagued humanity for thousands of years. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and is now a small, highly specialized organism. In contrast, the pathogen associated with the rare, late-onset, diffuse form of leprosy, M. lepromatosis, is nearly as large as M. leprae and has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system, and that the two pathogens have retained many of the same functions. These findings suggest that the two pathogens have retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system for a long time, and that they have been able to adapt to this new niche. This may be important for understanding the evolution of the disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we provide a complete solution to this problem for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We show that the entanglement dynamics is described by a set of coupled quantum integrable systems, which can be solved exactly. Our result provides a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, and it is expected to be useful for the study of interacting systems in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, which is associated with severe adverse events. In contrast, live attenuated vaccines are safe and can be used for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be used for mass vaccination.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was the most common vector during this period. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of infectious diseases in the past and today.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal behavior and cognition. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which are the basic units of information processing, has been neglected. This study shows that the evolution of brain numbers is more complex than brain size and that it is a key factor in the evolution of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main substrate for the severing activity of cofilin. However, the molecular mechanism of cofilin action is not fully understood. Here, we show that cofilin is able to enhance severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. This mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a molecular explanation for the role of twist in the action of cofilin and may have implications for our understanding of other mechanochemical processes. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of twist in the cytoskeleton and in cell motility.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, a sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose versus glucose remain unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. Our results have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. Future studies are needed to determine whether these findings can be generalized to the population level. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This finding has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the role of social networks in society.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences that are translated into proteins are modified in the cell. These modifications can have a variety of effects on protein synthesis, including changing the rate of translation and the identity of the amino acid added to the protein. We report here that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can alter the rate of translation and the identity of the amino acid added to the protein. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA can have a modest impact on protein synthesis, and that this impact can be enhanced by the presence of other modifications.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or of outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote health and well-being and help sustain optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a central theme in the study of evolution in the water. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to test the importance of potential drivers of body size in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. Our results provide a quantitative test of the importance of aquatic lifestyle in driving body size in mammals. They also provide a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and respond by increasing the activity of a chemosensory system that regulates virulence. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to cause disease.

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global problem. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, including the first global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the presence of pesticides in surface water is a global problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback to humans and the possibility of the emergence of new variants. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for the virus. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This work provides a critical step toward the development of effective strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus in wildlife and the environment. This article is protected by copyright. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the dams, and some of the solutions.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the source of this inflammation is still debated. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the major toxic species in AD, and that they are responsible for the initiation of the inflammatory response. We also show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is the main source of inflammation in AD. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct steps are involved. This study adds to the list of proteins that fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA molecules. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is normally inactive, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme, and that it prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonstandard amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing immunosuppression during sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon stored in all of the living organisms on Earth. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of the biosphere, including the first estimate of the biomass of marine biota. We show that humans have a disproportionately large impact on the biomass of mammals, fish, and plants. Our results highlight the importance of the biomass of humans and other species in the context of the global carbon cycle. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of humans on the global carbon cycle.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and present a toy model for pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a promising material for energy storage. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be made a conductor by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be made a superconductor by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of new devices and applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a major focus of research in the field of peptide chemistry. Here, we report the structure of a unique peptide, NCR044, and its antifungal activity. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to the receptor−ligand interface switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of VWD mutations and explains the pathophysiology of the disorder. The mechanism is also consistent with the effects of force on other proteins. The results suggest that the mechanism of action of many drugs that increase the binding of proteins to their receptors is to switch the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of force on many proteins.

The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately connected to human health. The viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in human health. The database is available for download and is searchable through a web interface.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of the ACI process makes it difficult to be well represented in climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to measure the aerosol–cloud interaction processes. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to become a significant contributor to the understanding of ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. Thus, this technique is expected to be a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to be a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be 15 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is unknown. Here we report the results of thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes, which provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the flow of ions across the membrane. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the regulation of cell excitability and the control of ion homeostasis. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are regulated by the opening and closing of their pore gates. In this study, we found that the K+ channel BK has a unique mode of C-type inactivation, which is closed state-dependent. This finding provides a new perspective for the study of the regulation of K+ channels and may be helpful for the development of drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the key steps in the parasite’s life cycle is the invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), which is required for the parasite to complete its life cycle. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC membrane, which may help to facilitate invasion. This finding would suggest that the invasion process is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, which could be exploited in the development of new treatments.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a promising material for energy storage. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity, and its electrical properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electrical conductivity can be controlled reversibly by applying strain. This opens up new opportunities for controlling the electrical properties of diamond, which can be used for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza disease and may inform the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of seasonal influenza outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is indirect and limited to a few specific sites. Here, we provide evidence for a tree-like structure of the brain’s language representation in a broad set of areas, including multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal sites. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to combine words into phrases, and that this operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our findings provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is involved in many important biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of redundant genes. It is expected to be useful for understanding the function and evolution of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding and satiety. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals, and this response is attenuated by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that this response is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and yield, and the most important limiting factor for crop production in many regions of the world. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow the delivery of nitrogen to the plant only when it is needed, thus improving the efficiency of nitrogen use and reducing the risk of N over-fertilization. Here, we report the development of a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are made up of cellular tissue and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider, Larinioides sclopetarius, has a hearing system that is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is used to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider’s outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. These features may be useful for applications in biomimetic sensing, medicine, and biotechnology. This study provides a unique perspective on the evolution of hearing and the role of outsourcing and supersizing in the design of novel sensing systems. It also provides a model system for studying the evolution of extended phenotypes and the regenerative repair of the body and its appendages.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target of the neutralizing antibodies that protect against severe COVID-19. We engineered the RBD to improve its manufacturability and immunogenicity. The engineered RBD was presented on a virus-like particle (VLP), which reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. The engineered RBD may be used to improve the efficacy of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 and other viruses. The engineered RBD may also be used to develop diagnostics and therapeutics.

The role of the ALK receptor in development and cancer is well established. Here we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK are activated by zebrafish and human ALKALs. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK in cancer and in the development of pigment cells.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The earliest plague genomes recovered to date are from the Late Neolithic period, and the number of genomes available to date is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has the potential to mitigate climate change by sequestering carbon (C) in soils. However, the efficacy of these practices in the United States remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase soil C storage on grasslands and croplands, but the magnitude of these effects is highly dependent on the type of crop and management system. Our results highlight the importance of integrating perennial pastures into agricultural systems and the need to develop and implement policies that incentivize the adoption of these practices.

The recent pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 has highlighted the need to understand the risk of zoonotic spillover of novel viruses. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to cause future pandemics. We also provide a platform for the public to contribute to the ongoing refinement of the database. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a similar alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is a convergently evolved adaptation that is likely to be favored by selection.

We present a study of the genetic structure of the population of the late 5th/early 6th century AD in Bavaria, Germany. We show that the genetic structure of the population is strongly correlated with geography, and that the genetic structure of the population is very different from that of the modern population. This indicates that the population was not in equilibrium, and that the population was subject to a number of processes that contributed to the shaping of the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future outbreaks of MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses

We report the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance and the potential of cloud-based metagenomic sequencing to inform public health response. This work is a step toward the development of a global surveillance platform for undifferentiated febrile illness.

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus by a complex of DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). This complex is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for eukaryotic DNA replication. It also provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for eukaryotic DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to replicate DNA. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate DNA. This polymerase can amplify short DNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the polymerase can serve as the basis for a complete RNA-based life cycle, including the replication of genetic information.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the treatment is also similar. The current treatment is mainly based on the immune response of the body. The results of this study show that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical patients immediately, and the mortality is significantly reduced.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in this process has not been explored. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work provides a new perspective on the role of natural products in fungal metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this pathway may be important for fungal interactions with other microbes. This work also provides a model for the discovery of other fungal natural products that bind and impact metal homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on other planets. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals and is derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous silica is derived from multiple aqueous solutions, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are derived from multiple aqueous solutions. The diagenesis of these materials is complex and is likely to have been influenced by the local environment and the rover’s Curiosity.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. Here, we show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are not fixed, but can be modified by natural selection. Our findings can be used to predict the future distribution of frost damage and to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is not clear. Here we show that Th17 cells can induce colitis in mice, but that this requires the development of Th1-like cells from a subset of Th17 precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease, but that the Th17 cell population is not the only source of pathogenic cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key cells for muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This study will help us to understand the disease mechanism and develop new therapies for ALS. This method will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to arthropods is emerging, but the mechanisms by which microbes influence their vectors are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We identify a protein in the pathogen that alters the microbiota, and we show that this protein is responsible for the changes in the microbiota. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen modifies the microbiota of its vector to enhance transmission. This knowledge will be useful in the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and provide new insights into the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the stratosphere plays a significant role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we describe a new mechanism for color change, which is based on the ability of a protein to bind biliverdin, a compound that is normally found in the blood. This mechanism is present in anurans, and has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 expression is increased in BCSCs, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes the maintenance of BCSCs, which are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The use of fetal animal skin for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well established. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, allowing a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. Our results provide a time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium has not been well studied. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a potential mechanism for RORα in the intestinal epithelium and may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 8.3 Å resolution. This structure provides a detailed view of the receptor binding domain and allows us to understand the structural changes that occur when the spike protein undergoes mutations that alter its interaction with the receptor.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are the key to understanding the origin of the periodic table. In this work, we propose a new way to measure the chemical properties of atoms, which can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. Our results are of fundamental importance for chemistry and can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Fire is a key climate-driven disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems, but the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and the resulting carbon cycle feedbacks using a coupled climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are more complex, and the risk of more extreme fires regionally means that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a model for studying the evolution of mutualism. We show here that the squid provides a single glycan to the symbiont at a specific time of day, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the organ of light. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbiont, thereby contributing to the stability of the mutualism. This is the first example of a glycan being used to regulate the activities of a symbiont.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it integrates topic modeling and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers in many domains.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. Our study shows that this event was the consequence of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. We provide evidence for the existence of plague reservoirs in medieval Europe, but not in the Mediterranean, which suggests that the disease was not established in the region until the 15th century.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly across the Pacific Ocean, causing the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that the virus is the likely cause of the disease and that it has been present on the Pacific coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge. Here we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in suppressing the growth of AML cells in vitro and in vivo. We also show that the antibodies are effective in suppressing the growth of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) and a 164-nucleotide RNA (denoted AzuR). We found that AzuC interacts with the glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also found that the RNA and RNA-binding protein, AzuR, compete for binding to the carbon utilization genes cadA and galE. The results suggest that the protein and RNA functions compete for the same binding sites. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate carbon utilization.

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to identify CDR changes that can improve the binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.
