Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in the United States. However, their assessments are qualitative and subjective, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the assessments of a large number of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more amenable to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the development of early warning systems for agricultural production anomalies.

Language is a uniquely human ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear, with some studies finding an increase in soil respiration with warming and others finding no change. Our analysis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements reveals that the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across biomes, with no consistent pattern. Our results suggest that soil respiration may be more responsive to warming in colder climates compared with warmer climates, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major function, photosynthesis, and the acquisition of a new function, the acquisition of nutrients. We show that the transition to heterotrophy is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the number of genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to heterotrophy relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was caused by a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. However, the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the prolonged rainfall deficit remains unclear. Here, we use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a quantitative assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought and its future intensification. It also provides a scientific basis for the development of drought risk management strategies in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic quasicrystal was discovered in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, in 1945. Here, we report the discovery of a second, and we believe the oldest, anthropogenic quasicrystal in the red trinitite, which was formed in the aftermath of the second nuclear test, the Soviet test “Tsar” in 1949.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that is used by all life. The biosynthesis of the pigments that mediate this process is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. This pathway is highly conserved, and the enzymes that catalyze it are highly similar. Here we report the discovery of three classes of enzyme in oxygenic phototrophs, and discuss their evolution.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of factors, including cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors. Neuroinflammation is also regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) signaling, which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. In this study, we identified a critical role of MAP3K signaling in neuroinflammation. We also identified cell-type–specific roles of MAP3K signaling in neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that MAP3K signaling may be a promising target for reducing neuroinflammation. We propose MAP3K signaling as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases and autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past few decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility observed in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches. This work is the first to report cross-national evidence on the prevalence of negativity biases in human reaction to news content. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content to date. The results suggest that, on average, news content is more negative in most countries, and that there is considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The findings help account for the tendency for news around the world to be predominantly negative, and they highlight the potential for more positive content to be more effective in attracting audiences. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling and homeostasis. Mutations in the SO(2) channel components ORAI1 and STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 that cause a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization and accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading and the propagation of disease in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the role of protein aggregates in disease propagation in general. This study provides a platform for studying the role of protein aggregates in disease propagation in general.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). This inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also report the discovery of a glycine-importing inhibitor of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a finding that may lead to the development of a new class of targeted therapy. These findings may lead to the development of a new class of targeted therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. We propose that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, which leads to the aggregation of these proteins. Our results suggest that the pathogenesis of ALS is driven by a set of metastable proteins, which are prone to aggregation in motor neurons. Thus, our findings may provide a rationale for the use of drugs that target metastable proteins in the treatment of ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous period is often considered to be the age of dinosaurs. However, the story of the origin of the plants is much more complex. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. The study of this plant, based upon more than 1,000 specimens, provides a detailed analysis of the morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction. The study suggests that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that lives and reproduces below the surface of the water. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in virology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been difficult to study. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which span ∼40 thousand years of human evolution. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results are important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the evolution of B19V in particular. They also have implications for the origin of human diseases. Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate of sea level rise predicted by climate models. This finding is important because it suggests that climate models are capturing the key physical processes that control the rate of sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment in MERS-CoV infection.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a model for studying the evolution of mutualism. We show here that the squid provides a single glycan to the symbiont at a specific time of day, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the organ of light. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbiont, thereby contributing to the stability of the mutualism. This is the first example of a glycan being used to regulate the activities of a symbiont.
This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools by changing the mindset of teachers. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that the sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection of other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, MERS-CoV S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other forms of environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 78.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.9%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our findings have implications for the food systems of other countries and sectors. They also highlight the importance of studying the impact of interventions at the population level, rather than just the impact on individuals.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we report a systems-level view of how six of the most prominent oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a foundation for the discovery of surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. They also suggest that the surfaceome is a major target for cancer therapy.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV, which may contribute to immune evasion. These results provide a molecular basis for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may be useful in the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also provide a new perspective for the study of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by other factors. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been selected for analysis. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We also discuss the implications of selective inference for the interpretation of results from complex statistical models.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a key factor for the development of ECs. ETV2 is able to induce the expression of multiple transcription factors that are important for EC development, and thus, it is able to induce the development of ECs from various sources. Furthermore, ETV2 is able to induce the development of ECs in vivo. These findings provide a new approach for the development of ECs and the treatment of vascular disorders. Thus, the development of ETVECs will be a useful tool for understanding the development of ECs and for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. This study demonstrates that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands exhibit a severe impairment in iridophore patterning. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of ligand-activated RTKs in the development of the zebrafish body coloration. It also provides a model system for further exploration of the physiological role of ligand-activated RTKs in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a multifactorial disease, and the molecular bases of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the cause of annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of these viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been well established. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in mediating the atheroprone hemodynamic environment and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. Here, we demonstrate that YAP/TAZ is activated by the atheroprone hemodynamic environment and plays a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in mediating the atheroprone hemodynamic environment and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of these diseases are not fully understood, but the recent outbreak has prompted global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. This work provides a better understanding of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV and can be used to inform the design of future clinical trials. This article is protected by copyright. Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of human activities and climate change. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algae, known as coral bleaching. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the early stages of bleaching and identifies the processes that contribute to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new strategies for the conservation of coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. Here, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a hub of communication with the microbiome, which can influence the activity of the epithelium and vice versa. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which is important for the development of tumors and the maintenance of the tumorigenic state. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer patients.

Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients relapse despite treatment. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1. We also found that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab reduced the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibited the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice, and improved the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is still a matter of debate. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions that occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also highlights the importance of inland fisheries for food security in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on freshwater fisheries makes them vulnerable to the impacts of fishing pressure and other threats to biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of riverine fisheries and to identify regions where alternative approaches to food security are needed.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material lead to a large capacity and low operating potential range, which are crucial for achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new perspective for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, recombination is also the primary mechanism for the generation of genetic variation. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive and emotional functions. The present study provides a method to identify and validate the resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The method is based on the analysis of metabolic signals, which are not subject to the fluctuations of the fMRI signal. The results show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topologically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this network is subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. The results show that the dominant resting state network is deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. These findings have important implications for the study of the resting brain and for the development of new imaging methods.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is conserved in all organisms. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because it is also found on pre-mRNAs. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that this association is maintained in vitro. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the severity of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier alteration and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene, SlTNH1, that is essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be useful in improving the flavor of other nitrogenous-rich fruits. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results highlight that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits. This is a critical finding for understanding the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning and the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, and its neurons are thought to encode information about the local environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the topological structure of the environment, are anatomically distinct from other neurons, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a more detailed picture of the organization of the MEC circuit. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra are the classic targets of the nigrostriatal dopamine pathway. Here we report the existence of a previously unknown subsystem within the dopamine-containing nigro system that is formed by striosome–dendron bouquets. These formations are composed of striosomal axons that branch into dopamine-containing dendrites and are intertwined with other neurons and glial cells. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine-containing system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we seek to be understood. We are often able to do this by reading the signals that others send us. In this paper, we show that one of the most robust signals of connection is the speed at which people respond to each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cells, called SAN cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that causes the heart to beat. The SAN is a highly specialized organ that must be able to maintain a constant heart rate in order to maintain blood pressure and oxygen delivery to the body. In this study, we show that the activity of the SAN is regulated by a process that involves the activity of calcium channels in the SAN cells. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms that regulate the activity of the SAN and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the earth’s crust, and its beneficial effects on plant growth and development have been well documented. However, the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well studied. Here, we report that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Abridged)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. We also show that the delivery of siRNAs to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

Eutrophication of lakes and rivers is a global problem, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, the relative importance of small versus large tributaries is poorly understood. We show that small tributaries of large lakes can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. This finding suggests that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, as they may be more likely to fuel algal blooms in nearshore areas. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and provide a framework for understanding and managing nutrient loading to large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes work available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the way in which the dynamics of a mechanical system can be biased toward states that extremize the energy of the system.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause a disruption of cortical microcircuitry that can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can be tolerated in the absence of NMDAR-Abs, suggesting that the presence of NMDAR-Abs is necessary to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the pathophysiology of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis and may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the presence of NMDAR-Abs may be necessary to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which may have implications for the treatment of patients with NMDAR-Abs. Finally, our findings may also be relevant to other conditions in which changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal abnormalities.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global-scale injection of organic matter–derived carbon and anoxia, and that the event was linked to a glacial–interglacial climate state. Our results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt warming and can be used to inform our understanding of the current warming.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of the complex is to provide the force for the release of secretory vesicles from the trans Golgi network. The exocyst complex is conserved in all kingdoms of life, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Sex determination is a key evolutionary process that shapes the sex ratio of a population and the sex-specific traits of an organism. In vertebrates, sex determination is often controlled by a single locus, which can result in two sexes, but can also result in more than two sexes. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple alleles controlling sex determination in a fish species, and find that multiple alleles can produce a modular system of secondary sexual characteristics, allowing for a variety of phenotypes in each sex. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to the accumulation of reactive intermediates and damage. In this study, we show that the presence of Fe in the retina can promote the oxidation and degradation of a class of reactive intermediates that are implicated in the loss of photoreceptor cells. These findings have implications for the treatment of retinal diseases and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from damage. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization, as they have a high number of species that are highly specialized on a single prey type. However, the evolution of specialization in siphonophores has been considered a dead end, as the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Our study shows that siphonophore specialization is not a dead end, and that it can evolve into generalism. We also show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles is linked to the evolution of prey type. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a derived hand in the hominin species Ardipithecus ramidus. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). This inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also report the discovery of a glycine-importing inhibitor of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a finding that may lead to the development of a new class of targeted therapy. These findings may lead to the development of a new class of targeted therapy.

This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy. This finding is important because it shows that the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood, and that the role of forests in improving diets and nutrition is not being fully recognized. The study also provides evidence that increasing food production via agricultural intensification may not be the only way to improve people’s diets, and that natural landscapes can play an important role in this process. The study has implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
